awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Influence of electric fields on liquid-to-solid phase change associated with clathrate hydrate formation
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Investigation of the fundamental mechanisms underlying electric field-induced formation of hydrates

Clathrate hydrates are water-based crystalline solids consisting of a guest molecule (methane, carbon dioxide, tetrahydrofuran, cyclopentane and others) trapped in a lattice of water molecules. Hydrates can be the basis of novel applications in many energy-water related areas such as natural gas transportation, desalination and carbon sequestration. A significant challenge associated with hydrate formation is the long wait time before hydrates start forming (nucleate), which can range from hours to days. Recent studies indicate that applied electrical voltages can significantly accelerate hydrate formation, and reduce the wait time by a factor of hundred or more. This electro-nucleation concept can enable rapid and controlled synthesis of hydrates for the above applications, all of which require rapid hydrate formation. This project is a fundamental study of the mechanisms underlying electric-field induced formation of hydrates. The influence of electric charge, current flow, heat transfer and surface chemistry on hydrate formation will be analyzed for three kinds of hydrates. Overall, this work will lead to seminal contributions in the fields of hydrates and liquid-to-solid phase change. The results of this project have the potential of completely eliminating the delay in hydrate formation, and enabling "on-demand" hydrate formation. Results from this research will be integrated into educational activities, which include the development of a graduate level course on Phase Change Heat Transfer and research opportunities for undergraduates and under-represented minorities.  

This project studies the electro-nucleation of three kinds of hydrates. In the first set of studies, hydrate formation from two immiscible liquids will be analyzed. Cyclopentane hydrate formation will be studied via experiments and analytical modeling to quantify the role of electric fields and interfacial charge on hydrate nucleation. In the second set of studies, hydrate formation from miscible liquids will be analyzed. Tetrahydrofuran hydrate formation will be analyzed to understand the influence of electric current and the resultant bubble generation on nucleation. The third set of studies will analyze electro-nucleation of methane hydrates, wherein hydrates nucleate at a liquid-gas interface at elevated pressures. This project includes nucleation-measurement experiments, analytical multiphysics modeling, and correlation development. Microfluidic cells will be fabricated to obtain statistically meaningful estimates of electro-nucleation. Specific outcomes of this project include measurements of electro-nucleation rates, and an understanding of the physics underlying the formation of various hydrates. This project will highlight the role of electric fields in fundamentally changing the nature of nucleation from stochastic to deterministic. Overall, this research will enable an in depth understanding of the influence of electrical phenomena on micro/mesoscale thermo-fluidic phenomena associated with hydrate formation.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project was a fundamental study on the influence of various promoting mechanisms (metal catalysts, electric fields, bubbles etc.) on nucleation and growth of clathrate hydrates (carbon dioxide (CO2) and others). Hydrates are chemical structures, in which a guest molecule is trapped in a cage of water molecules. Hydrate formation can enable new applications in carbon sequestration and desalination. Significant challenges underlying hydrate formation include the long induction (wait) time before hydrates nucleate, and very slow growth.

This project has created significant fundamental knowledge, and contributed to developing new avenues in the field of hydrate production. Most importantly, we have achieved the fastest production rate of CO2 hydrates; this advancement opens up new avenues for carbon sequestration. This research has been highly multidisciplinary in nature and has involved heat transfer, fluid mechanics, electrochemistry and materials. Specific outcomes include studies of various promoting mechanisms to speed up hydrate formation including i) use of metal catalysts like magnesium and aluminum, ii) electro-nucleation, iii) gas bubbling and iv) use of high thermal conductivity foam for heat removal.

Specific advancements are detailed in various archival journal articles and are summarized below:

2018 paper (Adv. Coll. Int. Sci.): This review article on fundamental mechanisms underlying electrofreezing covered experimental studies and molecular dynamics simulations from 1850 onwards.

2020 paper (J. Phy. Chem. Lett.): Discovered that aluminum speeds up the nucleation of CO2 hydrates significantly. This is due to nanobubbles formed by chemical reactions occurring at the interface of the metal-water (saturated with gas).

2020 paper (J. Fluid. Ph. Eq.): This was a detailed study on the use of thermodynamic features-driven machine learning algorithms for predicting conditions under which hydrates form.

2021 paper (Chem. Engg. Sci.): This was an analytical study on modeling growth of hydrate films. This model showed that gas diffusion governs film growth and not heat transfer, and flipped conventional understanding of this topic.

2021 paper (Sus. Chem. Engg):  This study on magnesium-based promotion of CO2 hydrates showed that magnesium significantly enhances nucleation of CO2 hydrates. We reported the fastest-ever nucleation of any gas hydrate via the use of magnesium.

2021 paper (Langmuir): This was a study of ice nucleation at the interface of the three-phase line.

2023 paper (Chem. Engg. J.): This study reported an analytical model to predict CO2 hydrate formation in bubble column reactors.

2023 paper (Sep. Pur. Tech.): This study reported the results of analytical modeling of CO2 hydrate formation from flue gases for carbon capture and carbon sequestration applications.

2024 article (under review): We have discovered that bubbling CO2 gas in water in the presence of magnesium significantly enhances CO2 hydrate formation. Our current results show CO2 hydrate formation, which is > 6X faster than state of the art. This result is even more significant as no chemical promoters or mechanical agitation is being used. Importantly, we have achieved high formation rates with saltwater, which is critical from a practical standpoint. This discovery is the subject of two patents and is the basis of significant current research, and possible future commercialization.

Broader Impacts

- This project has directly supported the PhD dissertations of three students at UT Austin in addition to providing research opportunities to undergraduate students.

- This research led to the conceptualization of new technology for sequestering carbon as CO2 hydrates on the seabed. This involves i) accelerated production of CO2 hydrates by intensifying mass & heat transfer, ii) transportation of CO2 hydrates to seabed disposal site, iii) compaction and sealing of hydrate plugs (to prevent dissociation) and disposal on the seabed.

- The PI’s team participated in the NSF I-Corps program in Winter 2022 to assess commercialization prospects for the above technology. This provided tremendous insights into further research and has provided excellent networking opportunities for students. The PI continues to conduct both fundamental and applied research leading towards a startup in the near future.

- The above technology is an alternative to the current technology of injecting CO2 underground for storage. The proposed approach of storing carbon as hydrates on the seabed has several benefits such as i) naturally occurring thermodynamic conditions for stability, ii) large real-estate for storage available globally compared to limited reservoirs for injection, iii) much lower area footprint required for storage versus injection, iv) low risk of leakage, seismic activity unlike injection.

- In addition to publications, the team also filed two patents related to the applications of this research for seabed carbon sequestration.
